item.title: Family Health Centre rewards patients for lifestyle disease management - The Hindu
item.description:
Family Health Centre Rewards Patients for Managing Lifestyle Diseases

Date: January 04, 2025 Source: IST

This article highlights a unique reward program launched by the Government Family Health Centre in Purakkad to inspire patients to effectively manage lifestyle diseases such as diabetes and hypertension.

  • Seventy-year-old Gomathi Gopalakrishnan received a two-gram gold biscuit for controlling her hypertension through a healthier lifestyle.
  • The 'Patharamattu Arogyam' program rewards patients who maintain their health, with other winners also receiving gold and silver coins.
  • A total of 178 patients were eligible for the rewards based on their consistent management of their health.
  • The initiative aims to prevent complications related to lifestyle diseases by encouraging adherence to treatment and regular monitoring.
  • The program was well-received and is expected to continue in the future.
“I am very happy that my blood pressure is now normal. The ‘Patharamattu Arogyam’ programme was a huge motivation...” - Gomathi Gopalakrishnan

The Family Health Centre's proactive approach is crucial amidst the rising prevalence of lifestyle diseases, aiming to support patients in maintaining their health effectively.

item.title: HMPV outbreak in China: Telangana govt issues dos and don'ts — check details here | Today News - Mint
item.description:
HMPV Outbreak in China: Telangana Government Issues Guidelines

Publication Date: Saturday

Source: Live Mint

The Telangana state government has issued a set of precautionary measures amid rising concerns over an HMPV outbreak in China, although no cases have been reported in Telangana.

Key Points

  • The Telangana health department reported no significant increase in respiratory infections compared to the previous year.
  • Dr. Atul Goyal advised general precautions and noted the lack of alarm.
  • Common symptoms of HMPV include cough, fever, nasal congestion, and shortness of breath.
  • The government issued specific do's and don'ts for citizens to follow.

Do’s

  • Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing.
  • Wash hands regularly with soap or sanitizer.
  • Avoid crowded places and maintain distance from sick individuals.
  • Stay home if feeling unwell.
  • Stay hydrated and consume nutritious food.

Don’ts

  • Do not reuse tissues or handkerchiefs.
  • Avoid close contact with sick individuals.
  • Steer clear of touching your face frequently.
  • Do not spit in public areas.
  • Avoid self-medication without professional advice.
“We are monitoring the situation in China. If an outbreak is detected that has the potential to spread to other areas, we can check its spread very quickly,” said Kerala Health Minister Veena George.

item.title: Throw away that cigarette, increase life expectancy: new study underlines benefits of smoking cessation - The Hindu
item.description:
Throw Away That Cigarette, Increase Life Expectancy: New Study Highlights Benefits of Smoking Cessation

Publication Date: January 04, 2025 Source: The Hindu

The article discusses a new study from University College London that reveals the severe impacts of smoking on life expectancy, indicating that quitting smoking can significantly enhance overall health and longevity.

  • One cigarette may reduce life expectancy by 20 minutes.
  • Smoking is linked to five of the top ten global causes of death.
  • In India, 38% of men and nearly 9% of women over 15 use tobacco.
  • Smokers lose healthy years equivalent to their total years of life.
  • Immediate health benefits are observed upon quitting, such as reduced blood pressure and improved taste and smell.
  • Smoking cessation can prevent significant loss of life over time.
“Generally, a smoker will have other co-morbid conditions. Also, their ability to tolerate treatment, and their ability to complete planned treatment may be compromised.” - Arvind Krishnamurthy

The study emphasizes the urgent need for smoking cessation to improve public health outcomes and longevity, highlighting that the benefits begin almost immediately and can lead to significantly longer and healthier lives.

item.title: No need to worry over reports of China flu outbreak: Kerala health minister - Business Standard
item.description:
No need to worry over reports of China flu outbreak: Kerala health minister

Date: Jan 04 2025 | Source: Press Trust of India, Thiruvananthapuram

Kerala Health Minister Veena George addresses concerns regarding the outbreak of viral infections in China, assuring that there is no need for public panic as they monitor the situation closely.

  • George stated there have been no reports of a pandemic-causing virus from China.
  • Extra caution is advised for vulnerable groups like pregnant women, children, and the elderly.
  • The National Centre for Disease Control is monitoring the situation and coordinating with international agencies.
  • Health officials describe the Human Metapneumovirus as comparable to common respiratory viruses.
"We are monitoring the situation in China. If an outbreak is detected that has the potential to spread to other areas, we can check its spread very quickly." - Veena George

The Kerala government is taking preventive measures and remains vigilant in response to reports from China, emphasizing the importance of awareness and health safety.

item.title: ‘We are monitoring situation in China’: Kerala health minister on HMPV fears - The Indian Express
item.description:
‘We are monitoring situation in China’: Kerala health minister on HMPV fears

Date: Recent news from Kerala

Source: The Indian Express

Kerala Health Minister Veena George addressed concerns regarding an outbreak of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in China, assuring the public that the situation is being closely monitored without cause for panic. She recommended that sick children stay home and advised masks for vulnerable populations.

  • The state is monitoring respiratory diseases, especially among children and the elderly.
  • Travelers from abroad, particularly China, will be monitored for respiratory symptoms.
  • The first Covid-19 case in India was reported in Kerala.
  • HMPV has been present globally, including Kerala, for over 50 years.
  • Local labs are equipped to detect HMPV and its potential strains.
“Those with respiratory symptoms should use masks. There is no reason to panic. We are monitoring the situation in China,” said the minister.

Overall, while the outbreak poses concerns, the health ministry is prepared and stresses that public health measures are in place.

item.title: Is it safe to travel to China amid HMPV outbreak scare and viral videos? All you need to know - The Economic Times
item.description:
Is it safe to travel to China amid HMPV outbreak scare and viral videos? All you need to know

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Economic Times

China faces a fresh outbreak of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV), raising concerns similar to the Covid-19 pandemic. This article discusses the current situation, travel safety, and responses from authorities.

Key Points:

  • There is a reported rise in HMPV cases in China, accompanied by videos showing overcrowded hospitals.
  • China insists it is safe for travelers, despite conflicting reports on the severity of the outbreak.
  • The HMPV virus shares symptoms with other respiratory illnesses, complicating the situation.
  • Indian authorities are monitoring the situation but report no alarming spikes in respiratory illnesses.
“Respiratory infections tend to peak during the winter season... The diseases appear to be less severe and spread on a smaller scale compared to the previous year.” - Mao Ning, Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson

This situation highlights the importance of monitoring health crises and the protocols for safely traveling during outbreaks.

item.title: Sitting is the new smoking: Sitting for too long could be behind 19 diseases; know easy lifestyle tweaks to avoid risk - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Sitting is the new smoking: Sitting for too long could be behind 19 diseases; know easy lifestyle tweaks to avoid risk

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Hindustan Times

In today's fast-paced world, prolonged sedentary activities contribute significantly to various chronic health conditions, including cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Experts emphasize the health risks associated with inactivity and advocate for small lifestyle changes to improve overall well-being.

  • Sedentary lifestyles are linked to numerous health risks, including obesity and depression.
  • The American College of Sports Medicine introduced initiatives to integrate physical activity assessments into routine healthcare.
  • Key findings reveal that active patients showed significantly better health markers than their inactive counterparts.
  • The Exercise Vital Sign (EVS) survey is proposed as a valuable tool for routine health screenings.
“Physical activity isn’t just about hitting the gym; it is a cornerstone of overall health.”

Encouraging routine screenings for physical activity can play a vital role in preventing chronic diseases and promoting healthier lifestyles.

item.title: 6 healthiest reasons to drink haldi shot every morning - The Times of India
item.description:
6 Healthiest Reasons to Drink Haldi Shot Every Morning

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

Turmeric is a potent spice known for its medicinal properties, primarily due to its active ingredient, curcumin. Consuming a haldi shot every morning can maximize its health benefits.

  • Fight inflammation: Curcumin can combat chronic inflammation, which is linked to various diseases.
  • May possess anti-cancer abilities: Some studies suggest curcumin may inhibit cancer cell growth.
  • Helps in arthritis and joint pain: Curcumin shows promise in reducing joint pain compared to NSAIDs.
  • Improves bowel motions: Haldi shots may enhance digestion and metabolism, promoting weight loss.
  • Helps in improving memory: Curcumin seems to increase BDNF levels, benefiting memory and learning.
  • Blood purifier: Turmeric acts as a natural blood purifier with antioxidant properties.
“When Asha Parekh revealed the reason behind quitting Bollywood: 'The hero would come at 6:30 pm for a 9:30 am shift'”

Incorporating haldi shots into your routine can offer multiple health benefits, making it a valuable addition to your morning regimen.

item.title: US Surgeon General bats for cancer warnings on alcohol: Here's how it causes breast cancer - CNBCTV18
item.description:
US Surgeon General Calls for Warning Labels on Alcohol Due to Cancer Risks

Publication Date: Friday | Source: CNBC

US Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy has issued an advisory labeling alcohol as a leading preventable cause of cancer and recommending warning labels on alcoholic beverages.

Dr. Murthy highlighted that alcohol is responsible for approximately 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 deaths annually in the US, exceeding fatalities from alcohol-related traffic incidents. He noted that alcohol is the third leading preventable cancer cause after tobacco and obesity.

  • Alcohol consumption is linked to breast cancer and is a significant modifiable risk factor.
  • The WHO reported that breast cancer diagnoses are escalating, with 1,579 cases daily in their European region.
  • In 2020, alcohol contributed to nearly 40,000 new breast cancer cases in the WHO European Region.
  • Dr. Marilys Corbex emphasized the need for public awareness regarding alcohol's role in breast cancer.
“Many people, including women, are not aware that breast cancer is the most common cancer caused by alcohol among women globally. By reducing alcohol consumption, they can reduce their risk of getting cancer.” – Dr. Marilys Corbex

WHO has classified alcohol as a Group 1 human carcinogen, linked to several cancers, and advises that there is no safe level of consumption.

The Surgeon General's proposal may face legislative hurdles amid opposition from the alcohol industry.

item.title: HMPV outbreak: Common symptoms seen in kids and adults - The Times of India
item.description:
HMPV outbreak: Common symptoms seen in kids and adults

Date: N/ASource: N/A

This article discusses the outbreak of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) and its common symptoms affecting both children and adults. It highlights the need for awareness about this virus and its impact on public health.

  • HMPV is known to cause respiratory infections.
  • Symptoms include cough, fever, and difficulty breathing.
  • The virus affects both healthy individuals and those with weakened immune systems.
  • It typically spreads through respiratory droplets.
“Awareness is key in managing the spread of HMPV.”

The increasing cases of HMPV underline the importance of recognizing symptoms and seeking medical attention promptly.

item.title: India monitoring reports of HMPV spread in China, no cause for panic: Health ministry - The Times of India
item.description:
India Monitoring HMPV Spread in China: Health Ministry Assures No Panic Required

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

The Indian government is closely monitoring reports of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) detected in China but assures the public there is no cause for panic.

  • The Health Ministry stated it is aware of the rise in HMPV cases in China.
  • Health officials recommend vigilance and adherence to health protocols but see no immediate threat to India.
  • The ministry is in contact with health authorities globally for updates and guidance.
“At this moment, we do not foresee a crisis; our healthcare system is prepared to handle any potential cases.” - Health Ministry Spokesperson

The government will continue to monitor the situation and keep the public informed with timely updates.

item.title: Closely monitoring influenza cases in India, no need to be alarmed: Govt on HMPV outbreak in China - The Indian Express
item.description:
Monitoring Influenza Cases: No Alarm Needed Over HMPV in China

Publication Date: January 2025   Source: Indian Express

The National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is closely monitoring respiratory and seasonal influenza cases in India, amidst reports of an outbreak of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in China. Official sources have stated that there is no need for alarm.

  • NCDC is in touch with international agencies regarding the HMPV outbreak.
  • There is no substantial increase in respiratory outbreak data for December 2024 in India.
  • DGHS Dr. Atul Goel likened HMPV to common cold viruses.
  • Precautions advised include respiratory etiquette and avoiding contact if symptomatic.
“There is nothing to be alarmed about the present situation,” - Dr. Atul Goel

As winter increases the outbreak of respiratory infections, hospitals are prepared with necessary supplies and beds. General precautions for respiratory infections are recommended.

item.title: US Surgeon-General Vivek Murthy wants cancer warning on alcohol: How does your drinking habit cause cancer? - The Indian Express
item.description:
US Surgeon-General Vivek Murthy Wants Cancer Warning on Alcohol

Date: Not mentioned in the article
Source: Indian Express

US Surgeon-General Vivek Murthy has called for alcoholic beverages to carry cancer warning labels, highlighting evidence that no level of alcohol consumption is safe when it comes to cancer risk.

  • Alcohol is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the US, following tobacco and obesity.
  • Consumption of just one drink per day can increase the risk for several cancers including breast, mouth, and throat.
  • Alcohol is classified as a group 1 carcinogen by the WHO, with no safe level of consumption.
  • Dr Murthy's report states alcohol increases the risk of at least seven types of cancer.
  • Dr Murthy draws parallels with India's anti-smoking campaigns as a model for addressing alcohol-related harm.
“Alcohol has been confirmed as a group 1 carcinogen... there is no safe level of alcohol,” - Dr Pankaj Chaturvedi

This initiative reflects a growing recognition of the health risks associated with alcohol consumption and aims to reduce the incidence of alcohol-related cancers.

item.title: ‘U.S. News & World Report’ Reveals Its Best Diets for 2025 - Everyday Health
item.description:
U.S. News & World Report Reveals Its Best Diets for 2025

Publication Date: January 2025
Source: U.S. News & World Report

As the new year begins, U.S. News & World Report has released its list of top diets for 2025, based on insights from a panel of health experts.

The rankings consider a variety of factors including health and lifestyle considerations, evaluating 13 different diets.

  • The Mediterranean diet is ranked as the best overall diet for the eighth consecutive year.
  • The DASH diet follows as the second best, focusing on low sodium and heart health.
  • The Flexitarian diet gains popularity, moving up to third place.
  • New categories include specific diets for health conditions and lifestyle needs, with the Mediterranean diet shining again.
  • Experts emphasize the importance of sustainable eating patterns for long-term success.
“Whenever you are too restrictive and have very specific things to follow every day you are basically setting yourself up for failure,” says Erin Palinski-Wade, RD.

In conclusion, the report encourages individuals to adopt diets that are manageable and promote long-term health benefits.

item.title: The Antibiotic Dilemma - The Times of India
item.description:
The Antibiotic Dilemma

Publication Date: N/A | Source: N/A

Antibiotics are a critical tool in modern medicine but face challenges such as resistance and overuse.

  • Growing antibiotic resistance threatens global health.
  • Misuse and overprescription contribute to the problem.
  • Importance of antibiotic stewardship in healthcare.
  • Strategies to combat resistance include public awareness campaigns.
"Antibiotic resistance is a significant public health issue that requires immediate attention."

In conclusion, addressing antibiotic resistance is essential for preserving the efficacy of these vital medications.

item.title: Cardiac cases rise as temp dips - The Times of India
item.description:
Cardiac cases rise as temp dips

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

The article discusses the increase in cardiac cases as temperatures drop, highlighting the health implications of cold weather on individuals with pre-existing conditions.

  • Rising cardiac cases attributed to colder temperatures.
  • Increased risk for individuals with heart conditions.
  • Health advisories for vulnerable populations during winter.
"Colder weather is associated with increased health risks for heart patients."

This rise in cardiac cases due to temperature dips emphasizes the need for public awareness and preparedness during cold seasons.

item.title: Alcohol stocks drop after US surgeon general calls for cancer warnings - The Indian Express
item.description:
Alcohol Stocks Decline Following US Surgeon General's Cancer Warning Proposal

Publication Date: September 29, 2023

Source: News Agency

The US Surgeon General has called for cancer warnings on alcoholic beverages, leading to a notable drop in shares of major spirits and brewing companies.

  • US Surgeon General Vivek Murthy stated that alcohol consumption increases the risk of various cancers.
  • Alcoholic drinks may start increasing cancer risk at just one drink per day.
  • Major companies like Brown-Forman and Constellation Brands experienced significant stock declines.
  • The surgeon general's recommendations may not be implemented immediately as Congress will decide on label changes.
  • Experts believe warning labels may have minimal impact on consumption habits.
“Most Americans tend to believe that nearly everything is okay in moderation, thus much as warning labels alone on cigarette packs did little to curb public smoking, I expect warning labels on alcohol to have little effect.” - Michael Ashley Schulman

Overall, the proposed warning labels on alcohol could reshape market dynamics, but the effectiveness remains uncertain.

item.title: Vagus nerve stimulation shows positive treatment effect in depression - Medical Xpress
item.description:
Vagus Nerve Stimulation Proves Effective for Treating Depression

Date: January 3, 2025 Source: HealthDay

Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) has been shown to significantly improve the quality of life among patients suffering from treatment-resistant depression, according to new studies.

  • Two studies published in the journal Brain Stimulation indicate positive outcomes for VNS in adults with treatment-resistant major depression.
  • Conducted by Dr. Charles R. Conway and colleagues, one trial involved 493 adults and demonstrated benefits from active VNS over sham treatments.
  • Results showed improvements based on clinician ratings and self-report measures of depressive symptoms.
  • A separate study led by Dr. A. John Rush also indicated that VNS was superior in enhancing quality of life and functional outcomes.
"What's really important here is that patients themselves were reporting that their lives were improving," said Dr. Conway.

This research supports VNS as a viable option for patients who have not responded to traditional antidepressant therapies.

item.title: ‘Nothing to be alarmed about’: Centre on China HMPV outbreak - Hindustan Times
item.description:
'Nothing to be alarmed about': Centre on China HMPV outbreak

Date: Jan 04, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

The Union health ministry has addressed concerns regarding a potential outbreak of the human metapneumovirus (HMPV) in China, affirming that there has been no significant increase in viral respiratory illness cases.

  • The health ministry stated there’s “no substantial increase” in respiratory illness cases.
  • Dr. Atul Goel emphasized the commonality of the virus, akin to any other respiratory virus.
  • Monitoring of both seasonal influenza and respiratory cases is ongoing.
  • Precautionary measures against spread are advised for respiratory infections.
“There is nothing to be alarmed about in the present situation,” said Dr. Goel.

In summary, officials maintain that while attention to HMPV is warranted, the public can remain calm as the healthcare system is prepared and no alarming rise in cases has been noted.

item.title: Alcohol stocks plunge after US surgeon general calls for cancer warnings | Today News - Mint
item.description:
Alcohol Stocks Plunge After US Surgeon General Calls for Cancer Warnings

Date: Not specified | Source: Live Mint

The U.S. Surgeon General's call for cancer warnings on alcohol labels has led to a decline in shares of spirits makers and brewers.

  • U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy highlighted the link between alcohol consumption and various cancers.
  • Shares of Brown-Forman and Molson Coors fell significantly, with Brown-Forman hitting its lowest price since April 2017.
  • There is uncertainty about when or if the labeling changes will be enacted as Congress will decide.
  • The decline also affected major European spirits brands like Diageo and Pernod Ricard.
“Most Americans tend to believe that nearly everything is okay in moderation... I expect warning labels on alcohol to have little effect,” said Michael Ashley Schulman.

This advisory may lead to further discussions regarding health warnings on alcoholic beverages, but its implementation remains unclear.

item.title: Alcohol stocks drop after US Surgeon General urges cancer warning on labels - Business Standard
item.description:
Alcohol Stocks Drop After US Surgeon General Urges Cancer Warning on Labels

Publication Date: Today
Source: Business Standard

The US Surgeon General's call for cancer warnings on alcoholic drink labels has triggered a decline in shares of leading spirits makers and brewers.

  • Surgeon General Vivek Murthy indicated that alcohol consumption increases the risk of various cancers, including breast and liver cancer.
  • Jack Daniel's parent company, Brown-Forman, saw shares drop nearly 3% in early trading, marking its lowest point since April 2017.
  • Other notable declines included Molson Coors and Constellation Brands, with Boston Beer experiencing a dip of up to 6.4%.
  • Implementation of the warning labels is uncertain, pending Congressional decision.
  • Expert Michael Ashley Schulman expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of such warning labels.
“Most Americans tend to believe that nearly everything is okay in moderation...I expect warning labels on alcohol to have little effect.” - Michael Ashley Schulman

In Europe, major spirits manufacturers like Diageo and Pernod Ricard faced significant stock declines as well, indicating broader market concern.

item.title: How to go vegan: our beginner’s guide to everything from essential supplements to meat alternatives - The Guardian
item.description:
How to go vegan: our beginner’s guide to everything from essential supplements to meat alternatives

Date & Source: Published on January 3, 2025 | Source: The Guardian

This article explores the fundamentals for anyone considering a vegan lifestyle, highlighting key products to substitute traditional meat and dairy, along with necessary supplements for health.

  • Veganism offers compassionate options for health and environmental concerns.
  • Essential products discussed include multivitamins, milk alternatives, and various meat substitutes.
  • Prominent recommendations include Vegan Society's Veg 1 multivitamins and various plant-based dairy products.
  • Dietitian insights included on essential nutrients, particularly B12 and Vitamin D.
  • Emphasis on creativity in cooking with wonky vegetables through services like Oddbox.
“The nutrient of most pressing concern is B12.” - Hazel Clarke, Dietitian

The guide summarizes practical steps and necessities for adopting a vegan diet, aiming to empower beginners with knowledge and resources.
